page.title: 06GOXHILL AIRFIELD.
page.content: The Airfield was used from June 1942 to February 1945 by the United States Army Airforce as a Fighter Training Station. A memorial to this use, in the form of a propeller set in a stone base, was unveiled, in 1984, by three of the bases's former servicemen. The propeller was part of a P38 Lockheed Lightning which crashed in Goxhill on May 26th, 1944. Mr J. Faulding farms the land which was the airfield. The buildings which remain hold farm machinery, livestock, fodder etc. The runways are occasionally used by crop spraying aircraft. In the past the hangars were used as a store for 400 Green Goddess fire engines. Combined harvesters are now serviced, prior to sale, in the two original hangars whilst a modern hangar sized building is an intervention store for barley - part of the E.E.C. grain mountain.
